# A OTHER RELATED WORK 

In this section, we discuss previous research on discriminative and generative probabilistic modeling and theoretical analyses of self-supervised learning that are relevant to our work.

## A. 1 Discriminative and Generative Probabilistic Models

Over the past decades, numerous probabilistic models have been developed for machine learning and pattern recognition problems (Grenander, 1970; Wu et al., 2019). Our work is closely related to previous works on discriminative probabilistic models for supervised and unsupervised learning, generative probabilistic models, and the recently proposed hybrid probabilistic models.

## A.1.1 Discriminative Probabilistic Models for Supervised Learning

For supervised learning, discriminative probabilistic models learn the conditional probability mass function $p(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x})$ of $\mathbf{y}$ given data $\mathbf{x}$. Since the 2010s, discriminative probabilistic models based on deep neural networks, such as ConvNets, have achieved tremendous success in supervised learning tasks (LeCun et al., 2015), where $\mathbf{y}$ is a class label from a finite set of categories. Despite the availability of million-scale datasets with label annotations (Deng et al., 2009; Kemelmacher-Shlizerman et al., 2016), scaling of these models is hindered by the enormous cost of collecting even larger curated datasets with label annotations.

## A.1.2 Generative Probabilistic Models

Generative probabilistic models typically focus on modeling the marginal distribution $p(\mathbf{x})$ of real data. In particular, an energy-based generative probabilistic model can be defined as $p_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})=$ $\frac{\exp \left(-E_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})\right)}{Z_{\theta}}$, where $E_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})$ is called the energy parameterized by $\theta$ and $Z_{\theta}$ is the partition function (LeCun et al., 2006). The intractable partition function is the key challenge in training an energy-based generative probabilistic model. Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling is a popular approach for calculating the gradient of the model parameter of the log-likelihood (Younes, 1999; Hinton, 2002; Gao et al., 2018; Du and Mordatch, 2019; Du et al., 2020). However, MCMC sampling is computationally expensive. MCMC-free approaches such as score-matching (Hyvärinen and Dayan, 2005; Song et al., 2020a; Song and Ermon, 2020; Song and Kingma, 2021; Song et al., 2020b) have been proposed to learn a model that can be used to generate the data through MCMC sampling in the inference phase. On one hand, generative modeling tasks are generally more challenging than discriminative ones. For discriminative tasks, such as classification and retrieval, it suffices to have the predicted conditional density $p(\cdot \mid \mathbf{x})$ of a relevant $\mathbf{y}$ be higher than that of an irrelevant $\mathbf{y}$. In contrast, generative tasks require a much more accurate high-dimensional density estimation to produce high-quality new data. On the other hand, training and inference on generative models typically demand more time and computational resources compared to discriminative models with a similar number of parameters.

# A.1.3 Hybrid Probabilistic Models 

Grathwohl et al. (2019) propose the Joint Energy-based Model (JEM) to simultaneously perform discriminative and generative learning by maximizing the likelihood of the joint distribution $p(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})$ for each image-label pair $(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})$, which can be factorized into an MCC problem solved by minimizing the CE loss and a generative modeling problem solved by the stochastic gradient Langevin dynamic (SGLD). When label annotations are absent, Wang et al. (2022) and Kim and Ye (2022) model the joint distribution $p\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)$ of a data point $\mathbf{x}$ and its augmented copy $\mathbf{x}^{\prime}$. Specifically, Wang et al. (2022) directly maximize the log-likelihood of the joint distribution $p\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)$ via adversarial learning, while Kim and Ye (2022) follow the idea of JEM to decompose the log-likelihood $\log p\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)$ into the sum of a generative term $\log p(\mathbf{x})$ and a discriminative term $\log p\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime} \mid \mathbf{x}\right)$. In Kim and Ye (2022), the gradient of the generative term is computed by multi-stage SGLD, and the discriminative term is approximated by the InfoNCE loss with a finite number of negative data. More recently, Bizeul et al. (2024) proposed the SimVAE method to model the joint distribution of semantically related data (e.g., different augmented copies of an image). The SimVAE maximizes the evidence lower bound (ELBO) of the log-likelihood by introducing the implicit latent structure of SimCLR into the variational autoencoder.

## A. 2 THEORY OF SELF-SUPERVISED REPRESENTATION LEARNING

In this section, we review additional papers on the theoretical properties of self-supervised representation learning from broader perspectives. The pioneering work by Arora et al. (2019) established a generalization bound for the minibatch-based InfoNCE loss that contrasts each positive pair with $k$ negative pairs in the sampled batch. They formally proved that the unsupervised error can bound the classification error of a constructed mean classifier. Following the settings in Arora et al. (2019), Lei et al. (2023) refined the analysis and improved the generalization bound by a factor of $k$. However, both results above depend on the assumption that the negative data points are independent from the anchor data points, which does not hold for contrastive learning algorithms used in practice ${ }^{5}$. Moreover, their results suffer from a limitation that the generalization error increases as the number of negatives $k$ increases, which contradicts the practice. HaoChen et al. (2021) proposed a spectral contrastive loss and established generalization bounds for both representation learning and the downstream classification. Based on a graph-dependent McDiarmid inequality and a U-statistics reformulation, Waida et al. (2023) proved the generalization bound of a kernel contrastive loss (KCL) without assuming the independence between anchors and negative data. They also provided theoretical guarantees on downstream zero-shot classification. Recently, Chen et al. (2024) established a generalization bound of the symmetric minibatch-based InfoNCE loss used in CLIP, under the assumption that an image and a text are conditionally independent given their common shared feature. However, the convergence rate of the generalization error is also worse when the minibatch size increases. They also proved that an approximate minimizer of the population loss leads to infinitesimal zero-shot classification error under the assumption that "good" encoding functions exist.
Besides, Wang and Isola (2020) proved that the asymptotics of the InfoNCE loss can be decomposed into two terms that optimize alignment and uniformity, respectively. Tian et al. (2020) showed that minimizing the InfoNCE loss can maximize the mutual information between two views/modalities since the loss is a lower bound of the mutual information. Tschannen et al. (2019) demonstrated that the success of InfoNCE loss cannot be fully attributed to information maximization because maximizing a tighter bound of mutual information leads to worse empirical performance. Nakada et al. (2023) show that the gradient descent steps of minimizing the symmetric InfoNCE loss of CLIP can be viewed as performing singular value decomposition (SVD) on a contrastive cross-covariance matrix when the representation is linear. Shwartz Ziv and LeCun (2024) proposed a unified framework for self-supervised learning based on information theory. They surveyed numerous existing approaches and demonstrated how their framework can encompass these approaches.

## A. 3 CONTRASTIVE LEARNING FOR LONG-TAILED DATA

Recently, several papers have proposed contrastive learning algorithms to address the challenge of long-tailed semantic distributions in real-world datasets. For instance, Assran et al. (2023b) introduced a method that applies a user-specified power-law prior to the distribution of representations

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{5}$ In practice, the negative data points for each anchor are from positive pairs of other anchors.

learned by Masked Siamese Networks (MSN). Based on the geometric harmonization method, Zhou et al. (2023b) proposed a bilevel objective to promote category-level uniformity instead of samplelevel uniformity in the representation space. Qiu et al. (2023) proposed a new robust contrastive loss inspired by distributionally robust optimization (DRO), which dynamically learns individualized temperature parameters for data points with frequent or rare semantics. The high-level ideas of these papers are related to our work, as we estimates the nonuniform $q^{(j)}=\sum_{j^{\prime}=1}^{n} p\left(\mathbf{y}_{j} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j^{\prime}}\right)$ to reduce the error of Monte Carlo integration, while the papers above also model the uniformity in data. However, our work is grounded in the statistical framework of DPM. It remains unclear how the losses above can be interpreted within the DPM framework or whether these approaches can address the non-diminishing error issue in GCL. Moreover, it is unclear about the effectivess of the approaches (Assran et al., 2023b; Zhou et al., 2023b) in bimodal self-supervised learning, as they focused on the unimodal setting. In Appendix G.3.1, we compare the experimental performance of our NUCLR with that of Qiu et al. (2023) in bimodal self-supervised learning.

# B MIS WITH A GENERAL WEIGHT FUNCTION FOR DPM 

We consider the following MIS-based estimator with a size- $m$ sample from each distribution $p(\cdot \mid$ $\left.\mathbf{x}_{j}\right)$ and a general weight function $\boldsymbol{\omega}$ for the integral $g\left(\mathbf{w} ; \mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathcal{Y}\right)=\int_{\mathcal{Y}} \exp \left(E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}\right) / \tau\right) d \mu(\mathbf{y})$ :

$$
\hat{g}\left(\mathbf{w} ; \mathbf{x}_{i}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}}, \boldsymbol{\omega}\right)=\sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{m} \sum_{l=1}^{m} \frac{\omega^{(j)}\left(\mathbf{y}_{j, l}\right)}{p\left(\mathbf{y}_{j, l} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j}\right)} \exp \left(E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j, l}\right) / \tau\right), \quad \hat{\mathbf{Y}}=\bigcup_{j=1}^{n}\left(\mathbf{y}_{j, 1}, \ldots, \mathbf{y}_{j, m}\right)
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\omega}$ is a weighting function such that $\omega(\mathbf{y})$ is on a probability simplex, $\forall \mathbf{y} \in \mathcal{Y}$. We denote $\hat{\mathbf{X}}:=\left\{\mathbf{x}_{1}, \ldots, \mathbf{x}_{n}\right\}, \Xi_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\omega}, \mathbf{y}_{j, l}\right):=\frac{\omega^{(j)}\left(\mathbf{y}_{j, l}\right)}{p\left(\mathbf{y}_{j, l} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j}\right)} \exp \left(E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j, l}\right) / \tau\right)$. We consider the "balance heuristic" $\omega_{\mathrm{bl}}^{(j)}(\mathbf{y})=\frac{p\left(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x}_{i}\right)}{\sum_{j=1}^{n} p\left(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j^{\prime}}\right)}, \forall \mathbf{y} \in \mathcal{Y}$ and $\forall j \in[n]$ proposed in Veach and Guibas (1995). Proposition 1 shows the unbiasedness of the estimator in (16) and justifies why we choose the balance heuristic.

Proposition 1. For each $\boldsymbol{\omega}$, we have that $\hat{g}\left(\mathbf{w} ; \mathbf{x}_{i}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}}, \boldsymbol{\omega}\right)$ is an unbiased estimator of the integral $g\left(\mathbf{w} ; \mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathcal{Y}\right)$; (ii) The balance heuristic $\boldsymbol{\omega}_{b l}$ minimizes $\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{m} \sum_{l=1}^{m} \Xi_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\omega}, \mathbf{y}_{j, l}\right)^{2} \mid \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right]$ among all possible weighting functions for any $i$, where $\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{m} \sum_{l=1}^{m} \Xi_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\omega}, \mathbf{y}_{j, l}\right)^{2} \mid \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right]$ is an upper bound of the variance $\operatorname{Var}\left[\hat{g}\left(\mathbf{w} ; \mathbf{x}_{i}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}}, \boldsymbol{\omega}\right) \mid \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right]$; (iii) If $\sum_{j^{\prime}=1}^{n} p\left(\mathbf{y}_{j, l} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j^{\prime}}\right) \geq \Omega(n), \forall j \in[n], l \in[m]$ almost surely and Assumptions 2 holds, the variance goes to zero when $n \rightarrow \infty$ or $m \rightarrow \infty$.

Proof. Since for any $j \in[n] \mathbf{y}_{j, 1}, \ldots, \mathbf{y}_{j, m}$ are i.i.d. distributed, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[\hat{g}\left(\mathbf{w} ; \mathbf{x}_{i}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}}, \boldsymbol{\omega}\right) \mid \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right]=\sum_{j=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{\omega^{(j)}\left(\mathbf{y}_{j, 1}\right)}{p\left(\mathbf{y}_{j, 1} \mid \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right)} \exp \left(E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j, 1}\right) / \tau\right) \mid \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right] \\
& =\sum_{j=1}^{n} \int_{\mathcal{Y}} \frac{\omega^{(j)}(\mathbf{y})}{p\left(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j}\right)} p\left(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j}\right) \exp \left(E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}\right) / \tau\right) d \mu(\mathbf{y}) \stackrel{*}{=} \int_{\mathcal{Y}} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \omega^{(j)}(\mathbf{y}) \exp \left(E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}\right) / \tau\right) d \mu(\mathbf{y}) \\
& =\int_{\mathcal{Y}} \exp \left(E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}\right) / \tau\right) d \mu(\mathbf{y})
\end{aligned}
$$

where $*$ is due to Tonelli's theorem. Since $\left\{\mathbf{y}_{j, l}\right\}_{j \in[n], l \in[m]}$ are mutually independent and for a specific $j, \mathbf{y}_{j, 1}, \ldots, \mathbf{y}_{j, l}$ are i.i.d., the variance of the estimator in (16) can be upper bounded as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Var}\left[\hat{g}\left(\mathbf{w} ; \mathbf{x}_{i}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}}, \boldsymbol{\omega}\right) \mid \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right]=\frac{1}{m} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\Xi_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\omega}, \mathbf{y}_{j, 1}\right)^{2} \mid \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right]-\frac{1}{m} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\Xi_{i, j}\left(\omega^{(j)}, \mathbf{y}_{j, 1}\right) \mid \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right]^{2} \\
& \leq \frac{1}{m} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\Xi_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\omega}, \mathbf{y}_{j, 1}\right)^{2} \mid \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right]=\frac{1}{m} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \int_{\mathcal{Y}} \frac{\omega^{(j)}(\mathbf{y})^{2} \exp \left(E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}\right) / \tau\right)^{2}}{p\left(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j}\right)} d \mu(\mathbf{y})
\end{aligned}
$$

Due to Tonelli's theorem, we have

$$
\sum_{j=1}^{n} \int_{\mathcal{Y}} \frac{\omega^{(j)}(\mathbf{y})^{2} \exp \left(E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}\right) / \tau\right)^{2}}{p\left(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j}\right)} d \mu(\mathbf{y})=\int_{\mathcal{Y}} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{\omega^{(j)}(\mathbf{y})^{2} \exp \left(E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}\right) / \tau\right)^{2}}{p\left(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j}\right)} d \mu(\mathbf{y})
$$

We can instead minimize the variance upper bound at each $\mathbf{y}$ pointwise. Then, minimizing $\sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{\omega^{(j)}(\mathbf{y})^{2} \exp \left(E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}\right) / \tau\right)^{2}}{p\left(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j}\right)}$ subject to the simplex constraint leads to $\omega_{\mathrm{hl}}^{(j)}(\mathbf{y})=\frac{p\left(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j}\right)}{\sum_{j^{\prime}=1}^{n} p\left(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j^{\prime}}\right)}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Var}\left[\hat{g}\left(\mathbf{w} ; \mathbf{x}_{i}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}}, \boldsymbol{\omega}_{\mathrm{hl}}\right) \mid \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right] & \leq \frac{1}{m} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\Xi_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\omega}_{\mathrm{hl}}, \mathbf{y}_{j, 1}\right)^{2} \mid \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right]=\frac{1}{m} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{\exp \left(E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j, 1}\right) / \tau\right)^{2}}{\left(\sum_{j^{\prime}=1}^{n} p\left(\mathbf{y}_{j, 1} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j^{\prime}}\right)\right)^{2}} \mid \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right] \\
& \leq \frac{1}{n m} \int_{\mathcal{Y}} p\left(\mathbf{y} \mid O_{j}\right) \exp \left(E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}\right) / \tau\right)^{2} d \mu(\mathbf{y})=O\left(\frac{1}{m n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Interestingly, the minimizer $\boldsymbol{\omega}_{\mathrm{hl}}$ of $\frac{1}{m} \mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{j=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{m} \Xi_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\omega}, \mathbf{y}_{j, j}\right)^{2} \mid \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right]$ does not depend on $\mathbf{x}_{i}$. We can obtain the estimator in (4) by plugging the balance heuristic $\boldsymbol{\omega}_{\mathrm{hl}}$ into (16) and letting $m=1$.

# C Performance of DPM on Downstream Zero-Shot Classification 

Suppose that the true conditional density function $p(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x})$ is generated by some $\mathbf{w}_{*} \in \mathcal{W}$, i.e., $p(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x})=p_{\mathbf{w}_{*}}(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x})=\frac{\exp \left(E_{\mathbf{w}_{*}}\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}\right) / \tau\right)}{\int_{\mathcal{Y}} \exp \left(E_{\mathbf{w}_{*}}\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right) / \tau\right) d \mu\left(\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right)}$. Then, the maximum likelihood estimator $\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{*}=$ $\arg \max _{\mathbf{w} \in \mathcal{W}} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \log p_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{y}_{i} \mid \mathbf{x}_{i}\right)$ with the random sample $\left\{\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)\right\}_{i=1}^{n}$ converges in probability to $\mathbf{w}_{*}$ under some mild assumptions (see Theorem 2.1 in Newey and McFadden (1994)).
Consider the downstream multi-class classification with $K>1$ distinct classes. The task is to predict the ground-truth label $c(\mathbf{x}) \in\{1, \ldots, K\}$ of a data $\mathbf{x} \in \mathcal{X}$. Suppose that there are $K$ subsets $\mathcal{Y}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{Y}_{K}$ of $\mathcal{Y}$ and any $\mathbf{y} \in \mathcal{Y}_{k}$ belongs to the $k$-th class. Moreover, the ground-truth label $c(\mathbf{x})$ of data $\mathbf{x}$ is $c(\mathbf{x})=\arg \max _{k \in[K]} \operatorname{Pr}(k \mid \mathbf{x})$. Given the model $\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{*}$ trained via MLE, the predicted label $c_{\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{*}}(\mathbf{x})$ of a data $\mathbf{x} \in \mathcal{X}$ can be obtained by the following 1-nearest neighbor (1-NN) classifier:

$$
c_{\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{*}}(\mathbf{x})=\underset{k \in[K]}{\arg \max } E_{\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{*}}\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}_{k}\right)
$$

where $\mathbf{y}_{k} \in \mathcal{Y}$ is an example of the $k$-th class. For instance, the example $\mathbf{y}_{k}$ of the $k$-th class of the downstream image classification could be "a photo of $\left\{\right.$ class_k$\}$ " when $\mathcal{X}$ is the image domain and $\mathcal{Y}$ is the text domain (Radford et al., 2021). Due to the monotonicity of the function $\exp (-/ \tau)$ and the expression of $p_{\mathbf{w}}$ in (1), we have $c_{\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{*}}(\mathbf{x})=\arg \max _{k \in[K]} E_{\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{*}}\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}_{k}\right)=\arg \max _{k \in[K]} p_{\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{*}}\left(\mathbf{y}_{k} \mid \mathbf{x}\right)$. As long as the probability mass $\operatorname{Pr}(k \mid \mathbf{x})$ on class $k$ is proportional to the probability density $p\left(\mathbf{y}_{k} \mid \mathbf{x}\right)$ on the example $\mathbf{y}_{k}$ of class $k$, the zero-one loss $\ell_{0 / 1}\left(\mathbf{x}, c(\mathbf{x}) ; \hat{\mathbf{w}}_{*}\right)=\mathbb{I}\left[c_{\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{*}}(\mathbf{x})+c(\mathbf{x})\right]$ on the data-label pair $(\mathbf{x}, c(\mathbf{x}))$ of the downstream classification approaches zero when $\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{*} \xrightarrow{p} \mathbf{w}_{*}$.

## D Proof of Theorem 1

The structure of our proof is as follows:

- Section D. 1 presents necessary lemmas for our generalization analysis.
- Section D. 2 decomposes the generalization error into two parts, which are handled by Section D. 3 and Section D.4, respectively.
- Section D. 5 provides bounds for Rademacher complexities of function classes parameterized by deep neural networks. The main theorem can be proved by combining (20), (21), (22), (23), (24), (27), (30), (31).

### D. 1 LEMMAS

The following two lemmas provide contraction lemmas on Rademacher complexities. Lemma 1 considers the class of real-valued functions, and Lemma 2 considers the class of vector-valued functions (Maurer, 2016; Lei et al., 2023). Let $\epsilon_{i}$ and $\epsilon_{i, j}$ be independent Rademacher variables, i.e., they take values in $\{+1,-1\}$ with the same probability.

Lemma 1 (Contraction Lemma, Thm 11.6 in Boucheron et al. (2013)). Let $\tau: \mathbb{R}_{+} \mapsto \mathbb{R}_{+}$be convex and nondecreasing. Suppose $\psi: \mathbb{R} \mapsto \mathbb{R}$ is contractive $(|\psi(t)-\psi(\bar{t})| \leq G|t-\bar{t}|)$ and $\psi(0)=0$. Then for any $\overline{\mathcal{F}}$ we have

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{c}} \tau\left(\sup _{f \in \mathcal{F}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} \psi\left(f\left(x_{i}\right)\right)\right) \leq \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{c}} \tau\left(G \sup _{f \in \mathcal{F}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} f\left(x_{i}\right)\right)
$$

We say that a function $\psi: \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is $G$-Lipschitz continuous w.r.t. $\left.\|\cdot\|_{2}\right.$ if $|\psi(x)-\psi(\mathbf{x})| \leq$ $G\left\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right\|_{2}$ for a $G>0$ and any $\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime} \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$.
Lemma 2. Let $\mathcal{F}$ be a class of bounded functions $f: \mathcal{Z} \mapsto \mathbb{R}^{d}$ which contains the zero function. Let $\tau: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$be a continuous, non-decreasing, and convex function. Assume $\tilde{g}_{1}, \ldots, \tilde{g}_{n}: \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ are $G$-Lipschitz continuous w.r.t. $\|\cdot\|_{2}$ and satisfy $\tilde{g}_{i}(\mathbf{0})=0$. Then

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{c}-\{\pm 1\}^{n}} \tau\left(\sup _{f \in \mathcal{F}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} \tilde{g}_{i}\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)\right)\right) \leq \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{c}-\{\pm 1\}^{n d}} \tau\left(G \sqrt{2} \sup _{f \in \mathcal{F}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{d} \epsilon_{i, j} f_{j}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)\right)
$$

The following lemma estimates the moment generating function of a Rademacher chaos variable of order 2 (De la Pena and Giné, 2012).
Lemma 3 (De la Pena and Giné 2012). Let $\epsilon_{i}, i \in[n]$ be independent Rademacher variables. Let $a_{i, j} \in \mathbb{R}, i, j \in[n]$. Then for $Z=\sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq n} \epsilon_{i} \epsilon_{j} a_{i j}$ we have

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{c}} \exp (|Z| /(4 e s)) \leq 2, \quad \text { where } s^{2}:=\sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq n} a_{i, j}^{2}
$$

The following lemma is a version of Talagrand's contraction lemma.
Lemma 4 (Lemma 8 in Mohri and Medina (2014)). Let $\mathcal{H}$ be a hypothesis set of functions mapping $\mathcal{X}$ to $\mathbb{R}$ and $\psi$ is $G$-Lipschitz functions for some $G>0$. Then, for any sample $S$ of $n$ points $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in \mathcal{X}$, the following inequality holds:

$$
\frac{1}{n} \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}}\left[\sup _{h \in \mathcal{H}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} \psi\left(h\left(x_{i}\right)\right)\right] \leq \frac{G}{n} \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}}\left[\sup _{h \in \mathcal{H}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} h\left(x_{i}\right)\right]
$$

# D. 2 Error Decomposition 

Considering $\log _{e} x \leq x-1$ for any $x>0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \tilde{\mathcal{L}}(\mathbf{w} ; \tilde{\mathbf{q}}, \tilde{\mathbf{S}})-\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w}) \\
& =\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}}\left[E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right]-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)+\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \tau \log \left(\tilde{g}\left(\mathbf{w} ; \mathbf{x}_{i}, \tilde{\mathbf{Y}}\right)\right)-\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}}[\tau \log g(\mathbf{w} ; \mathbf{x}, \mathcal{Y})] \\
& =\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}}\left[E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right]-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)+\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}}\left[\tau \log \frac{\sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{\tilde{q}^{(j)}} \exp \left(\left(E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)-1\right) / \tau\right)}{\tilde{f}_{\mathcal{Y}} \exp \left(\left(E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})-1\right) / \tau\right) d \mu(\mathbf{y})}\right] \\
& \leq \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}}\left[E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right]-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right) \\
& +\underbrace{\frac{C}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{d} \frac{1}{q^{(j)}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)\right)-\underline{C} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}}}\left[\int_{\mathcal{Y}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right) d \mu(\mathbf{y})\right]}_{\text {II }}
\end{aligned}
$$

where we define $\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}):=\frac{E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})-1}{\tau} \in[-2 / \tau, 0]$ such that $\exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right) \in[\exp (-2 / \tau), 1]$. Besides, and $\bar{C}:=\sup _{\mathbf{x} \in \mathcal{X}} \frac{\tau}{\int_{\mathcal{Y}} \exp \left(E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right) d \mu(\mathbf{y})}$. Due to Assumption $2, \bar{C} \leq \frac{\tau \exp (2 / \tau)}{\mu(\mathcal{Y})}<\infty$. In

practice, $\overline{C}$ could be much smaller than the worst-case value $\frac{\tau \exp (2 / \tau)}{\mu(\mathcal{Y})}$. Similarly, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w})-\hat{\mathcal{L}}(\mathbf{w} ; \tilde{\mathbf{q}}, \tilde{\mathbf{S}}) \leq & \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)-\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}}\left[E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right] \\
& +\bar{C}^{\prime} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}}\left[\int_{\mathcal{Y}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right) d \mu(\mathbf{y})\right]-\frac{\bar{C}^{\prime}}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{\bar{q}^{(j)}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\bar{C}^{\prime}=\frac{\tau|\bar{q}|}{n} \exp (2 / \tau)$.

# D. 3 Bounding TERM I 

Define the function class $\mathcal{E}:=\left\{(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}) \mapsto E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}) \mid \mathbf{w} \in \mathcal{W}\right\}$. Since $\left(\mathbf{x}_{1}, \mathbf{y}_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(\mathbf{x}_{n}, \mathbf{y}_{n}\right)$ are i.i.d. and Assumption 1 $\left(E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}) \in[-1,1]\right.$ for any $\left.\mathbf{w} \in \mathcal{W}\right)$, we can apply the McDiarmid's inequality to $\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}}\left[E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right]-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)$ and utilize the symmeterization argument following Theorem 3.3 in Mohri et al. (2018). With probability at least $1-\frac{\delta}{4}$,

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}}\left[E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right] \leq \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)+2 \mathfrak{R}_{n}(\mathcal{E})+6 \sqrt{\frac{\log (8 / \delta)}{2 n}}
$$

where $\mathfrak{R}_{n}(\mathcal{E}):=\mathbb{E}_{\tilde{\mathbf{X}}, \tilde{\mathbf{Y}}}\left[\hat{\mathfrak{R}}_{n}^{*}(\mathcal{E})\right], \hat{\mathfrak{R}}_{n}^{*}(\mathcal{E}):=\mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}}\left[\sup _{e \in \mathcal{E}} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)\right]$ is the empirical Rademacher complexity of $\mathcal{E}$ on the sample $\tilde{\mathbf{X}} \times \tilde{\mathbf{Y}}$, and $\epsilon_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{n}$ are Rademacher random variables. Similarly, we can also apply McDiarmid's inequality to $\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)-\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}}\left[E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right]$ and then use the symmetrization argument. With probability at least $1-\frac{\delta}{4}$,

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right) \leq \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}}\left[E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right]+2 \mathfrak{R}_{n}(\mathcal{E})+6 \sqrt{\frac{\log (8 / \delta)}{2 n}}
$$

Thus, with probability at least $1-\frac{\delta}{2}$, we have

$$
\left|\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)-\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}}\left[E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right]\right| \leq 2 \mathfrak{R}_{n}(\mathcal{E})+6 \sqrt{\frac{\log (8 / \delta)}{2 n}}
$$

## D. 4 BOUNDING TERM II

We decompose the term II in (20) as follows.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { II }=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{\bar{q}^{(j)}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)\right)-\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}}\left[\int_{\mathcal{Y}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right) d \mu(\mathbf{y})\right] \\
& =\underbrace{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n}\left(\frac{1}{\bar{q}^{(j)}}-\frac{1}{q^{(j)}}\right) \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)\right)}_{\text {II.a. }} \\
& +\underbrace{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{q^{(j)}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)\right)-\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}}\left[\int_{\mathcal{Y}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right) d \mu(\mathbf{y})\right]}_{\text {II.b. }} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, we have $|\Pi| \leq|\Pi . \mathrm{a}|+|\Pi . \mathrm{b}|$. Since $\exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right)=\exp \left(\left(E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})-1\right) / \tau\right) \leq 1$ for any $\mathbf{x} \in \mathcal{X}, \mathbf{y} \in \mathcal{Y}$, we have

$$
|\Pi . \mathrm{a}| \leq \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n}\left|\frac{1}{\bar{q}^{(j)}}-\frac{1}{q^{(j)}}\right| \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)\right) \leq \sum_{j=1}^{n}\left|\frac{1}{\bar{q}^{(j)}}-\frac{1}{q^{(j)}}\right|
$$

We define $\Gamma(\tilde{\mathbf{X}}, \tilde{\mathbf{Y}}):=\sup _{\mathbf{w}}\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{q^{(j)}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)\right)-\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}}\left[\int_{\mathcal{Y}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right) d \mu(\mathbf{y})\right]\right\}$. We denote that $\tilde{\mathbf{X}}_{\ell}=\left(\hat{\mathbf{X}} \backslash\left\{\mathbf{x}_{\ell}\right\}\right) \cup\left\{\mathbf{x}_{\ell}^{\prime}\right\}, \tilde{\mathbf{Y}}_{\ell}=\left(\hat{\mathbf{Y}} \backslash\left\{\mathbf{y}_{\ell}\right\}\right) \cup\left\{\mathbf{y}_{\ell}^{\prime}\right\}$, where $\left(\mathbf{x}_{\ell}^{\prime}, \mathbf{y}_{\ell}^{\prime}\right), \ldots,\left(\mathbf{x}_{n}^{\prime}, \mathbf{y}_{n}^{\prime}\right)$ are

i.i.d. to $\left(\mathbf{x}_{1}, \mathbf{y}_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(\mathbf{x}_{n}, \mathbf{y}_{n}\right)$. We denote that $q(\mathbf{y} ; \hat{\mathbf{X}}) \vDash \sum_{\mathbf{x} \in \hat{\mathbf{X}}} p(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x})$ such that $q^{(j)}=q\left(\mathbf{y}_{j} ; \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right)$. If $q^{(j)}=\sum_{j^{\prime}=1}^{n} p\left(\mathbf{y}_{j} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j^{\prime}}\right) \geq \Omega(n)$ almost surely, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\Gamma(\hat{\mathbf{X}}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}})-\Gamma\left(\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\ell}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}}\right)\right| \\
& =\left|\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{q^{(j)}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{\ell}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)\right)-\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{j} ; \hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\ell}\right)} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{\ell}^{\prime}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)\right)\right| \leq O(1 / n) \\
& |\Gamma(\hat{\mathbf{X}}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}})-\Gamma\left(\hat{\mathbf{X}}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}}_{\ell}\right)| \\
& =\left|\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{\ell} ; \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right)} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{\ell}\right)\right)-\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{\ell}^{\prime} ; \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right)} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{\ell}^{\prime}\right)\right)\right| \leq O(1 / n)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\mathbf{x}_{i}$ and $\mathbf{y}_{j}$ are mutually dependent only when $i=j$, we then apply the McDiarmid-Type inequalities for graph-dependent variables (Theorem 3.6 in Zhang et al. (2019)) to the term II.b and -II.b. With probability at least $1-\frac{\delta}{4}, \delta \in(0,1)$, we have

$$
\text { II.b } \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \text { II.b }\right]+O\left(\sqrt{\frac{10 \log (4 / \delta)}{n}}\right)
$$

Similarly, with probability at least $1-\frac{\delta}{4}, \delta \in(0,1)$, we have

$$
-\text { II.b } \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}}\{-\text { II.b }\}\right]+O\left(\sqrt{\frac{10 \log (4 / \delta)}{n}}\right)
$$

Let $\left(\mathbf{x}_{1}^{\prime}, \mathbf{y}_{1}^{\prime}\right), \ldots,\left(\mathbf{x}_{n}^{\prime}, \mathbf{y}_{n}^{\prime}\right)$ be a virtual sample i.i.d. to $\left(\mathbf{x}_{1}, \mathbf{y}_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(\mathbf{x}_{n}, \mathbf{y}_{n}\right)$. Denote that $\hat{\mathbf{X}}^{\prime} \vDash$ $\left\{\mathbf{x}_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, \mathbf{x}_{n}^{\prime}\right\}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}}^{\prime} \vDash\left\{\mathbf{y}_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, \mathbf{y}_{n}^{\prime}\right\}$. Due to (17), we have

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}}\left[\int_{\hat{\mathbf{y}}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right) d \mu(\mathbf{y})\right]=\mathbb{E}_{\hat{\mathbf{X}}^{\prime}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}}^{\prime}}\left[\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{j}^{\prime} ; \hat{\mathbf{X}}^{\prime}\right)} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{\prime}, \mathbf{y}_{j}^{\prime}\right)\right)\right]
$$

We can rewrite and decompose the $\mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}}\right.$ II.b $\left.^{\prime}\right]$ term as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \text { II.b }\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}}\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{q^{(j)}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)\right)-\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}}\left[\int_{\hat{\mathbf{y}}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right) d \mu(\mathbf{y})\right]\right\}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}}\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{q^{(j)}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)\right)-\mathbb{E}_{\hat{\mathbf{X}}^{\prime}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}}^{\prime}}\left[\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{j}^{\prime} ; \hat{\mathbf{X}}^{\prime}\right)} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{\prime}, \mathbf{y}_{j}^{\prime}\right)\right)\right\}\right] \\
& \leq \mathbb{E}_{\hat{\mathbf{X}}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}}, \hat{\mathbf{X}}^{\prime}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}}^{\prime}}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}}\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{i} ; \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right)} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)\right)-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{i}^{\prime} ; \hat{\mathbf{X}}^{\prime}\right)} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{\prime}, \mathbf{y}_{i}^{\prime}\right)\right)\right\}\right] \\
& \quad+\mathbb{E}_{\hat{\mathbf{X}}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}}, \hat{\mathbf{X}}^{\prime}, \hat{\mathbf{Y}}^{\prime}}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}}\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j \neq i} \frac{1}{q^{(j)}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)\right)-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j \neq i} \frac{1}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{j}^{\prime} ; \hat{\mathbf{X}}^{\prime}\right)} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{\prime}, \mathbf{y}_{j}^{\prime}\right)\right)\right\}\right] \\
& \leq O(1 / n)+\mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}}\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j \neq i} \frac{1}{q^{(j)}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)\right)-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j \neq i} \frac{1}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{j}^{\prime} ; \hat{\mathbf{X}}^{\prime}\right)} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{\prime}, \mathbf{y}_{j}^{\prime}\right)\right)\right\}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

the last step is due to the assumption $q\left(\mathbf{y}_{i} ; \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right)=\sum_{j^{\prime}=1}^{n} p\left(\mathbf{y}_{i} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j^{\prime}}\right) \geq \Omega(n)$. Next, we adapt the proof technique in Theorem 6 of Waida et al. (2023). W.l.o.g., we assume that $n$ is even (If $n$ is odd, we can apply the following analysis to the first $n-1$ terms in the summation, where $n-1$ is even. The last term in the summation is a $O(1 / n)$ term, which does not change the result). Suppose that $S_{n}$ is the set of all permutations (the symmetric group of degree $n$ ). Then, for each $s \in S$, pairs $\left(\mathbf{x}_{s(2 i-1)}\right), \mathbf{y}_{s(2 i)}\left(i=1, \ldots, n / 2\right)$ are mutually independent. Consider the alternative expression of a U-statistics of order 2 (See Appendix 1 in Clémencon et al. (2008)):

$$
\frac{1}{n(n-1)} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j \neq i} \frac{1}{q^{(j)}} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)\right)=\frac{1}{n!(n / 2)} \sum_{s \in S_{n}} \sum_{i=1}^{n / 2} \frac{1}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{s(2 i)} ; \hat{\mathbf{X}}\right)} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{s(2 i-1)}, \mathbf{y}_{s(2 i)}\right)\right)
$$

It then follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \text { II.b }\right] \leq O(1 / n)+\frac{n-1}{n / 2} \mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \frac{1}{n!} \sum_{s \in S_{n}} \frac{n / 2}{2}\left(\frac{\exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{s(2 i-1)} ; \mathbf{y}_{s(2 i)}\right)\right)}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{s(2 i)} ; \overline{\mathbf{X}}\right)}-\frac{\exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{s(2 i-1)}^{\prime} ; \mathbf{y}_{s(2 i)}^{\prime}\right)\right)}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{s(2 i)}^{\prime} ; \overline{\mathbf{X}}^{\prime}\right)}\right)\right] \\
& \leq O(1 / n)+\frac{n-1}{n / 2} \frac{1}{n!} \sum_{s \in S_{n}} \mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \sum_{i=1}^{n / 2}\left(\frac{\exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{s(2 i-1)} ; \mathbf{y}_{s(2 i)}\right)\right)}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{s(2 i)} ; \overline{\mathbf{X}}\right)}-\frac{\exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{s(2 i-1)}^{\prime} ; \mathbf{y}_{s(2 i)}^{\prime}\right)\right)}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{s(2 i)}^{\prime} ; \overline{\mathbf{X}}^{\prime}\right)}\right)\right] \\
& =O(1 / n)+\frac{n-1}{n / 2} \mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \sum_{i=1}^{n / 2}\left(\frac{\exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{2 i-1} ; \mathbf{y}_{2 i}\right)\right)}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{2 i} ; \overline{\mathbf{X}}\right)}-\frac{\exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{2 i-1}^{\prime} ; \mathbf{y}_{2 i}^{\prime}\right)\right)}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{2 i}^{\prime} ; \overline{\mathbf{X}}^{\prime}\right)}\right)\right] \\
& \leq O(1 / n)+\frac{2(n-1)}{n / 2} \mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \sum_{i=1}^{n / 2} \frac{\epsilon_{i} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{2 i-1} ; \mathbf{y}_{2 i}\right)\right)}{q\left(\mathbf{y}_{2 i} ; \overline{\mathbf{X}}\right)}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where we have used the symmetry between the permutations in $S_{n}$ and $\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right),\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{\prime}, \mathbf{y}_{i}^{\prime}\right)$. By Lemma 4 and the assumption $q\left(\mathbf{y}_{2 i} ; \overline{\mathbf{X}}\right)=\sum_{j^{\prime}=1}^{n} p\left(\mathbf{y}_{2 i} \mid \mathbf{x}_{j^{\prime}}\right) \geq \Omega(n)$, we further get

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \text { II.b }\right] \leq O(1 / n)+O(1 / n) \mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \sum_{i=1}^{n / 2} \epsilon_{i} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{2 i-1} ; \mathbf{y}_{2 i}\right)\right)\right]
$$

Define the function class $\overline{\mathcal{G}}=\left\{(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}) \mapsto \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right) \mid \mathbf{w} \in \mathcal{W}\right\}$. Then, we define the following empirical Rademacher complexity

$$
\hat{\mathfrak{R}}_{n / 2}^{-}(\overline{\mathcal{G}} ; s):=\frac{2}{n} \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n / 2}}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \sum_{i=1}^{n / 2} \epsilon_{i} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{s(2 i-1)} ; \mathbf{y}_{s(2 i)}\right)\right)\right]
$$

We further define the Rademacher complexity $\mathfrak{R}_{n / 2}^{-}(\overline{\mathcal{G}}):=\max _{s \in S_{n}} \mathbb{E}_{\overline{\mathbf{X}}, \overline{\mathbf{Y}}}\left[\hat{\mathfrak{R}}_{n / 2}^{-}(\overline{\mathcal{G}} ; s)\right]$. We can also apply the symmetrization argument above to bound $\mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}}\{-\text { II.b }\}\right]$. Due to Assumption 1, we can bound the II.b term as: With probability $1-\frac{2}{3}, \delta \in(0,1)$, we have

$$
|\text { II.b }| \leq O(1) \hat{\mathfrak{R}}_{n / 2}^{-}(\overline{\mathcal{G}} ; s)+O\left(\frac{1}{n}+\sqrt{\frac{10 \log (4 / \delta)}{n}}\right)
$$

# D. 5 BOUNDING RAdEMACHER COMPLEXITIES 

We consider the specific similarity function:

$$
E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})=E_{1}\left(\mathbf{w}_{1} ; \mathbf{x}\right)^{\top} E_{2}\left(\mathbf{w}_{2} ; \mathbf{y}\right)
$$

We consider $L$-layer neural networks

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E_{1}\left(\mathbf{w}_{1} ; \mathbf{x}\right) \in \mathcal{F}_{1, L}=\left\{\mathbf{x} \rightarrow \sigma\left(W_{1, L} \sigma\left(W_{1, L-1} \ldots \sigma\left(W_{1,1} \mathbf{x}\right)\right)\right):\left\|W_{1, l}\right\|_{F} \leq B_{l}\right\} \\
& E_{2}\left(\mathbf{w}_{2} ; \mathbf{y}\right) \in \mathcal{F}_{2, L}=\left\{\mathbf{y} \rightarrow \sigma\left(W_{2, L} \sigma\left(W_{2, L-1} \ldots \sigma\left(W_{2,1} \mathbf{y}\right)\right)\right):\left\|W_{2, l}\right\|_{F} \leq B_{l}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Suppose that $W_{1, l} \in \mathbb{R}^{d_{1, l} \times d_{1, l-1}}, W_{2, l} \in \mathbb{R}^{d_{2, l} \times d_{2, l-1}}$ and $d_{1,0}=d_{1}, d_{2,0}=d_{2}, d_{1, L}=d_{2, L}=d_{L}$. Define $W_{l}^{\top}=\left(W_{l}^{(1)}, \ldots, W_{1}^{\left(d_{l}\right)}\right)$, where $W_{l}^{(\iota)}$ is the $\iota$-th row of matrix $W_{l}$. The following results are adaptions of the results in Golowich et al. (2018).

## D.5.1 BOUNDING $\mathfrak{R}_{n}(\mathcal{E})$

Define $h: \mathbb{R}^{2 d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ as $h(\mathbf{v})=\mathbf{v}_{1}^{\top} \mathbf{v}_{2}$, where $\mathbf{v}=\binom{\mathbf{v}_{1}}{\mathbf{v}_{2}}$ and $\mathbf{v}_{1}, \mathbf{v}_{2} \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. It is clear that $E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})=$ $h\left(E_{1}\left(\mathbf{w}_{1} ; \mathbf{x}\right), E_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{w}_{2} ; \mathbf{y}\right)\right)$. Due to Assumption 2, we have $\left\|E_{1}\left(\mathbf{w}_{1} ; \mathbf{x}\right)\right\|_{2} \leq 1$ and $\left\|E_{2}\left(\mathbf{w}_{2} ; \mathbf{y}\right)\right\|_{2} \leq$ 1. For any $\mathbf{v}=\binom{\mathbf{v}_{1}}{\mathbf{v}_{2}}, \mathbf{v}^{\prime}=\binom{\mathbf{v}_{1}^{\prime}}{\mathbf{v}_{2}^{\prime}}$ and $\mathbf{v}_{1}, \mathbf{v}_{2}, \mathbf{v}_{1}^{\prime}, \mathbf{v}_{2}^{\prime} \in[0,1]^{d}$, we have

$$
\left(h(\mathbf{v})-h\left(\mathbf{v}^{\prime}\right)\right)^{2} \leq 2\left(\mathbf{v}_{1}^{\top}\left(\mathbf{v}_{2}-\mathbf{v}_{2}^{\prime}\right)\right)^{2}+2\left(\left(\mathbf{v}_{1}-\mathbf{v}_{1}^{\prime}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{v}_{2}^{\prime}\right)^{2} \leq 2\left\|\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{v}^{\prime}\right\|_{2}^{2}
$$

where we have used $(a+b)^{2} \leq 2 a^{2}+2 b^{2}$ and the decomposition $\mathbf{v}_{1}^{\top} \mathbf{v}_{2}-\left(\mathbf{v}_{1}^{\prime}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{v}_{2}^{\prime}=\mathbf{v}_{1}^{\top}\left(\mathbf{v}_{2}-\mathbf{v}_{2}^{\prime}\right)+$ $\left(\mathbf{v}_{1}-\mathbf{v}_{1}^{\prime}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{v}_{2}^{\prime}$. Thus, we can conclude that $h$ is 1-Lipschitz continuous to $\mathbf{v}$ and apply Lemma 2 to the function $E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})=h\left(E_{1}\left(\mathbf{w}_{1} ; \mathbf{x}\right), E_{2}\left(\mathbf{w}_{2} ; \mathbf{y}\right)\right)$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tilde{\mathfrak{R}}_{n}^{*}(\mathcal{E})= & \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}}\left[\sup _{\epsilon \in \mathcal{E}} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} E\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)\right] \\
\leq & \frac{1}{n} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{e}_{1}, \mathbf{e}_{2} \in\{ \pm 1\}^{n d_{L}}}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}}\left(\epsilon_{1}^{(i, i)} E_{1}^{(i)}\left(\mathbf{w}_{1}, \mathbf{x}_{i}\right)+\epsilon_{2}^{(i, i)} E_{2}^{(i)}\left(\mathbf{w}_{2}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)\right)\right] \\
\leq & \frac{1}{n} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{e}_{1} \in\{ \pm 1\}^{n d_{L}}}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \epsilon_{1}^{(i, i)} E_{1}^{(i)}\left(\mathbf{w}_{1}, \mathbf{x}_{i}\right)\right]+\frac{1}{n} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{e}_{1}, \mathbf{e}_{2} \in\{ \pm 1\}^{n d_{L}}}\left[\sup _{\mathbf{w}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \epsilon_{2}^{(i, i)} E_{2}^{(i)}\left(\mathbf{w}_{2}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)\right] \\
= & \frac{1}{n} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{e}_{1} \in\{ \pm 1\}^{n d_{L}}}\left[\sup _{W_{1, L}, f_{1, L-1} \in \mathcal{F}_{1, L-1}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \epsilon_{1}^{(i, i)} \sigma\left(f_{1, L-1}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{1, L}^{(i)}\right)\right] \\
& +\frac{1}{n} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{e}_{2} \in\{ \pm 1\}^{n d_{L}}}\left[\sup _{W_{2, L}, f_{2, L-1} \in \mathcal{F}_{2, L-1}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \epsilon_{2}^{(i, i)} \sigma\left(f_{2, L-1}\left(\mathbf{y}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{2, L}^{(i)}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

For simplicity, we can only consider one of the terms above and neglect the index of embedding networks (1 or 2). Let $\mathbf{x}_{i}$ be one of $\mathbf{x}_{i}$ and $\mathbf{y}_{i}$. Cauchy-Schwarz and $(\sup x)^{2} \leq \sup x^{2}$ imply

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{e} \in\{ \pm 1\}^{n d_{L}}}\left[\sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \epsilon^{(i, i)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L}^{(i)}\right)\right] \\
& \leq\left(\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{e} \in\{ \pm 1\}^{n d_{L}}}\left[\left(\sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \epsilon^{(i, i)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L}^{(i)}\right)\right)^{2}\right]\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \\
& \leq\left(\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{e} \in\{ \pm 1\}^{n d_{L}}}\left[\sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \epsilon^{(i, i)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L}^{(i)}\right)\right)^{2}\right]\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

For a $\lambda>0$, Jensen's inequality implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{e} \in\{ \pm 1\}^{n d_{L}}}\left[\sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \epsilon^{(i, i)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L}^{(i)}\right)\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =\frac{1}{\lambda} \log \exp \left(\lambda \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{e}}\left[\sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \epsilon^{(i, i)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L}^{(i)}\right)\right)^{2}\right]\right) \\
& \leq \frac{1}{\lambda} \log \left(\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{e}} \exp \left(\lambda \sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \epsilon^{(i, i)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L}^{(i)}\right)\right)^{2}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We utilize the following facts: (i) $\sup _{x} x^{2} \leq \max \left\{\left(\sup _{x} x\right)^{2},\left(\sup _{x}(-x)\right)^{2}\right\}$ and for a Rademacher random variable $\epsilon$, we have $\epsilon,-\epsilon$ are i.i.d.; (ii) Lemma 1 with $\tau(t)=\exp \left(\lambda t^{2}\right)$ and $\sigma$ is 1-Lipschitz; (iii) $(\sup x)^{2} \leq \sup x^{2}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{e}} \exp \left(\lambda \sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \epsilon^{(i, i)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L}^{(i)}\right)\right)^{2}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(i)}{=} 2 \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{e}} \exp \left(\lambda\left(\sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \epsilon^{(i, i)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L}^{(i)}\right)\right)^{2}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(0)}{\leq} 2 \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{e}} \exp \left(\lambda\left(\sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \epsilon^{(i, i)} f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L}^{(i)}\right)^{2}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(00)}{=} 2 \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{e}} \exp \left(\lambda \sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \epsilon^{(i, i)} f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L}^{(i)}\right)^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Due to (iv) $\left\|W_{l}\right\|_{F} \leq B_{l}$ for each $l \in[L]$, we further have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}} \exp \left(\lambda \sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{s=1}^{d_{L}} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L}^{(s)}\right)\right)^{2}\right) \\
& \leq 2 \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}} \exp \left(\lambda \sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}}\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)\right\|_{2}\left\|W_{L}^{(s)}\right\|_{2}\right)^{2}\right) \\
& \leq 2 \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}} \exp \left(\lambda \sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}}\left\|W_{L}\right\|_{F}^{2} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}}\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)\right\|_{2}^{2}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(n) \text { (o) }}{=} 2 \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}} \exp \left(\lambda B_{L}^{2} \sup _{f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}}\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)\right\|_{2}^{2}\right) \\
& =2 \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}} \exp \left(\lambda B_{L}^{2} \sup _{W_{L-1}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-2}} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}}\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} \sigma\left(W_{L-1} f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)\right)\right\|_{2}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Due to the positive-homogeneous property of the activation function $\sigma(\cdot)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}}\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} \sigma\left(W_{L-1} f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)\right)\right\|_{2}^{2}=\sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}}\left\|\left(\begin{array}{c}
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L-1}^{(1)}\right) \\
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L-1}^{(d_{L-1})}\right)
\end{array}\right)\right\|_{2}^{2} \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \sum_{r=1}^{d_{L-1}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L-1}^{(r)}\right)\right)^{2}=\sum_{r=1}^{d_{L-1}}\left\|W_{L-1}^{(r)}\right\|_{2}^{2} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} \frac{W_{L-1}^{(r)}}{\left\|W_{L-1}^{(r)}\right\|_{2}}\right)\right)^{2} \\
& \leq\left\|W_{L-1}\right\|_{F}^{2} \max _{r \in\left[d_{L-1}\right]} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} \frac{W_{L-1}^{(r)}}{\left\|W_{L-1}^{(r)}\right\|_{2}}\right)\right)^{2} \\
& \leq B_{L-1}^{2} \sup _{\mathbf{w}:\left\{\mathbf{w}\right\}_{2} \leq 1} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{w}\right)\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, we can obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}} \exp \left(\lambda \sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{s=1}^{d_{L}} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L}^{(s)}\right)\right)^{2}\right) \\
& \leq 2 \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}} \exp \left(\lambda B_{L}^{2} B_{L-1}^{2} \sup _{\left\{\mathbf{w}\right\}_{2} \leq 1, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-2}} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{w}\right)\right)^{2}\right) \\
& \leq 2 \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}} \exp \left(d_{L} \lambda B_{L}^{2} B_{L-1}^{2} \sup _{\left\{\mathbf{w}\right\}_{2} \leq 1, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-2}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{w}\right)\right)^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Applying Lemma 1 with $\tau_{\lambda}(t)=\exp \left(d_{L} \lambda B_{L}^{2} B_{L-1}^{2} t^{2}\right)$ gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}} \exp \left(\lambda \sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{s=1}^{d_{L}} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L}^{(s)}\right)\right)^{2}\right) \leq 2 \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}}\left[\tau_{\lambda}\left(\sup _{\left\{\mathbf{w}\right\}_{2} \leq 1, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-2}}\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{w}\right)\right\}\right)\right] \\
& \leq 2 \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}}\left[\tau_{\lambda}\left(\sup _{\left\{\mathbf{w}\right\}_{2} \leq 1, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-2}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{w}\right)\right)\right]+2 \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}}\left[\tau_{\lambda}\left(\sup _{\left\{\mathbf{w}\right\}_{2} \leq 1, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-2}}-\sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{w}\right)\right)\right] \\
& =4 \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}}\left[\tau_{\lambda}\left(\sup _{\left\{\mathbf{w}\right\}_{2} \leq 1, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-2}}\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{w}\right)\right\}\right] \leq 4 \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}}\left[\tau_{\lambda}\left(\sup _{\left\{\mathbf{w}\right\}_{2} \leq 1, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-2}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{w}\right\}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where in the last step we have used the positive-homogeneous property of $\sigma(\cdot)$ (e.g., analysis similar to handling the supremum over $W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}$ ). Applying the inequality above recursively over the layers leads to

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{c}} \exp \left(\lambda \sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L}^{(i)}\right)\right)^{2}\right) \leq 2^{L} \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}}\left[\tau_{\lambda}\left(\prod_{l=1}^{L-2} B_{l}\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} \mathbf{x}_{i}\right\|_{2}\right)\right]
$$

Plug the inequality above into (29):
$\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{c} \in\{s 1\}^{n d_{L}}}\left[\sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L}^{(i)}\right)\right)^{2}\right] \leq \frac{1}{\lambda} \log \left(2^{L} \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}} \exp \left(d_{L} \lambda\left(\prod_{l=1}^{L} B_{l}^{2}\right)\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} \mathbf{x}_{i}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right)\right)$.
Let $\tilde{\lambda}=d_{L} \lambda\left(\prod_{l=1}^{L} B_{l}^{2}\right)$ and choose $\lambda=\frac{1}{8 e s d_{L}\left(\prod_{l=1}^{L} B_{l}^{2}\right)}, s=\left(\sum_{1 \leq i \leq j \leq n}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{\top} X_{i}\right)^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}$. Then, $\tilde{\lambda}=$ $1 /(8 e s)$ and we can apply Lemma 3 to show $\mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}}\left[\exp \left(2 \tilde{\lambda} \sum_{1 \leq i \leq j \leq n} \epsilon_{i} \epsilon_{i} \mathbf{x}_{i}^{\top} X_{i}\right)\right] \leq 2$ such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}} \exp \left(\tilde{\lambda}\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} \mathbf{x}_{i}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right)=\mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}}\left[\exp \left(\tilde{\lambda} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\|_{2}^{2}+2 \tilde{\lambda} \sum_{1 \leq i \leq i \leq n} \epsilon_{i} \epsilon_{i} \mathbf{x}_{i}^{\top} X_{i}\right)\right] \\
& =\exp \left(\tilde{\lambda} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right) \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}}\left[\exp \left(2 \tilde{\lambda} \sum_{1 \leq i \leq i \leq n} \epsilon_{i} \epsilon_{i} \mathbf{x}_{i}^{\top} X_{i}\right)\right] \leq 2 \exp \left(\tilde{\lambda} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\lambda=\frac{1}{8 e s d_{L}\left(\prod_{l=1}^{L} B_{l}^{2}\right)}$ and $s^{2} \leq \sum_{1 \leq i \leq j \leq n}\left\|\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\|_{2}^{2}\left\|\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\|_{2}^{2} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right)^{2}$, we can obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{c} \in\{s 1\}^{n d_{L}}}\left[\sup _{W_{L}, f \in \mathcal{F}_{L-1}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{d_{L}} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{(i, s)} \sigma\left(f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} W_{L}^{(i)}\right)\right)^{2}\right] \leq \frac{1}{\lambda} \log \left(2^{L+1} \exp \left(\tilde{\lambda} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right)\right) \\
& =\frac{(L+1) \log 2}{\lambda}+d_{L}\left(\prod_{l=1}^{L} B_{l}^{2}\right) \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\|_{2}^{2} \leq d_{L}\left(\prod_{l=1}^{L} B_{l}^{2}\right)(8(L+1) e \log 2+1) \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\|_{2}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Due to (28), we can obtain

$$
\hat{\mathfrak{R}}_{\mathrm{n}}^{*}(\mathcal{E})=\mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n}}\left[\sup _{e \in \mathcal{E}} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \epsilon_{i} E\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)\right] \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \sqrt{d_{L}\left(\prod_{l=1}^{L} B_{l}^{2}\right)(8(L+1) e \log 2+1)}\left(c_{1}+c_{2}\right)
$$

# D.5.2 BOUNDING $\mathfrak{R}_{n / 2}^{-}(\overline{\mathcal{G}})$ 

We define the dataset $\hat{\mathbf{D}}_{s}:=\left\{\left(\mathbf{x}_{s(1)}, \mathbf{y}_{s(2)}\right), \ldots,\left(\mathbf{x}_{s(n-1)}, \mathbf{y}_{s(n)}\right)\right\}$. Consider $\mathcal{E}:=\{(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}) \mapsto$ $\left.E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}) \mid \mathbf{w} \in \mathcal{W}\right\}$ and the following two function classes

$$
\overline{\mathcal{E}}:=\{(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}) \mapsto \bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}) \mid \mathbf{w} \in \mathcal{W}\}, \quad \overline{\mathcal{G}}=\left\{(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}) \mapsto \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})\right) \mid \mathbf{w} \in \mathcal{W}\right\}
$$

The empirical Rademacher complexities of $\overline{\mathcal{E}}, \overline{\mathcal{G}}$ on $\hat{\mathbf{D}}_{s}$ can be defined as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \hat{\mathfrak{R}}_{n / 2}^{-}(\overline{\mathcal{E}} ; s)=\mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n / 2}}\left[\frac{2}{n} \sup _{\mathbf{w}} \sum_{i=1}^{n / 2} \epsilon_{i} \bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{s(2 i-1)}, \mathbf{y}_{s(2 i)}\right)\right] \\
& \hat{\mathfrak{R}}_{n / 2}^{-}(\overline{\mathcal{G}} ; s)=\mathbb{E}_{\epsilon_{1: n / 2}}\left[\frac{2}{n} \sup _{\mathbf{w}} \sum_{i=1}^{n / 2} \epsilon_{i} \exp \left(\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{s(2 i-1)}, \mathbf{y}_{s(2 i)}\right)\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $t \mapsto \exp (t)$ is 1-Lipschitz when $t \leq 0$. Due to Lemma 4 and $\bar{E}_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})=\left(E_{\mathbf{w}}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})-1\right) / \tau$,

$$
\hat{\mathfrak{R}}_{n / 2}^{-}(\overline{\mathcal{G}} ; s) \leq \hat{\mathfrak{R}}_{n / 2}^{-}(\overline{\mathcal{E}} ; s)=\frac{1}{\tau} \hat{\mathfrak{R}}_{n / 2}^{-}(\mathcal{E} ; s)
$$

Then, we can bound $\hat{\mathfrak{R}}_{n / 2}^{-}(\mathcal{E} ; s)$ in the way similar to bounding $\hat{\mathfrak{R}}_{n}^{+}(\mathcal{E})$ in Section D.5.1.

# E Proof of Theorem 2 

Proof. The problem in (8) is equivalent to

$$
\min _{\zeta \in \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \tau \log \left(\sum_{j=1}^{n} \exp \left(\left(E\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)-E\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)-\zeta^{(j)}\right) / \tau\right)\right)+\frac{1}{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \zeta^{(j)}\right\}
$$

We define that $\Phi(\zeta):=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \tau \log \left(\sum_{j=1}^{n} \exp \left(\left(E\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)-E\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)-\zeta^{(j)}\right) / \tau\right)\right)+\frac{1}{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \zeta^{(j)}$. Due to the first-order optimality condition, any optimal solution $\zeta_{*}$ to (8) satisfies

$$
\exp \left(\zeta_{*}^{(j)} / \tau\right)=\sum_{j^{\prime}=1}^{n} \frac{\exp \left(E\left(\mathbf{x}_{j^{\prime}}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right) / \tau\right)}{\sum_{i^{\prime}=1}^{n} \exp \left(\left(E\left(\mathbf{x}_{j^{\prime}}, \mathbf{y}_{i^{\prime}}\right)-\zeta_{*}^{j^{\prime}}\right) / \tau\right)}, \quad \forall j \in[n]
$$

Then, we can obtain (9) by changing the variable $\hat{q}^{(j)}=\exp \left(\zeta_{*}^{(j)} / \tau\right)$ for any $j \in[n]$.
Due to the property of the log-sum-exp function and $E\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right) \in[-1,1]$, we have

$$
\Phi(\zeta) \geq \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \max _{j \in[n]}\left\{E\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)-E\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)-\zeta^{(j)}\right\}+\frac{1}{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \zeta^{(j)} \geq-2-\min _{j \in[n]} \zeta^{(j)}+\frac{1}{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \zeta^{(j)} \geq-2
$$

Thus, $\Phi(\zeta)$ is proper convex. Besides, each line parallel to the diagonal line $\partial_{n}=\{\zeta \mid \zeta=z \mathbf{1}_{n}, z \in$ $\mathbb{R}\}$ can be expressed as $\overline{\partial}_{n}(\mathbf{b})=\left\{\zeta \mid \zeta=z \mathbf{1}_{n}+\left[\begin{array}{c}0 \\ \mathbf{b}\end{array}\right], z \in \mathbb{R}\right\}$ with some unique $\mathbf{b} \in \mathbb{R}^{n-1}$. For example, in the case $n=2$, a line $\partial_{2}(b)$ with some $b \in \mathbb{R}$ can be rewritten as $\partial_{2}(b)=\left\{\zeta \mid \zeta^{(2)}=\zeta^{(1)}+b\right\}$, which is parallel to the diagonal line $\partial_{2}=\left\{\zeta \mid \zeta^{(2)}=\zeta^{(1)}\right\}$. For any point $\zeta$ on a line $\partial_{n}(\mathbf{b})$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi(\zeta) & =\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \tau \log \left(\sum_{j=1}^{n} \exp \left(\left(E\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)-E\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)-z+b^{(j)}\right) / \tau\right)\right)+z+\frac{1}{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} b^{(j)} \\
& =\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \tau \log \left(\exp (-z / \tau) \sum_{j=1}^{n} \exp \left(\left(E\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)-E\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)-b^{(j)}\right) / \tau\right)\right)+z+\frac{1}{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} b^{(j)} \\
& =\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \tau \log \left(\sum_{j=1}^{n} \exp \left(\left(E\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)-E\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)-b^{(j)}\right) / \tau\right)\right)+\frac{1}{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} b^{(j)}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the expression on the R.H.S is fixed when $z$ varies. Then, the value of $\Phi(\zeta)$ does not change along the line $\partial_{n}(\mathbf{b})$. Note that every point $\zeta \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ is uniquely located on one line $\partial_{n}(\mathbf{b})$ parallel to the diagonal line $\partial_{n}$. Thus, if $\zeta_{*}=z_{*} \mathbf{1}_{n}+\left[\begin{array}{c}0 \\ \mathbf{b}_{*} \\ \hline\end{array}\right]$ with specific $z_{*} \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\mathbf{b}_{*} \in \mathbb{R}^{n-1}$ is a minimum of $\Phi(\zeta)$, then any point on the line $\partial_{n}\left(\mathbf{b}_{*}\right)$ is a minimum of $\Phi(\zeta)$.
There may exist uncountably infinite many $\mathbf{b}_{*} \in \mathbb{R}^{n-1}$ and every point on $\partial_{n}\left(\mathbf{b}_{*}\right)$ minimizes $\Phi(\zeta)$. However, we can rule out such a case since the set of minima of a proper convex function is convex and $\Phi(\zeta)$ is strictly convex along any direction other than the diagonal and parallel lines ${ }^{6}$. Thus, there is only a unique $\mathbf{b}_{*} \in \mathbb{R}^{n-1}$ and any point on $\partial_{n}\left(\mathbf{b}_{*}\right)=\left\{\zeta \mid \zeta=z \mathbf{1}_{n}+\left[\begin{array}{c}0 \\ \mathbf{b}_{*} \\ \hline\end{array}\right], z \in \mathbb{R}\right\}$ minimizes $\Phi(\zeta)$, i.e., the minimum of $\Phi(\zeta)$ is unique up to an arbitrary scalar additive term $z \in \mathbb{R}$.

## F More Discussions on NUCLR in Algorithm 1
## F. 1 Computational and Memory Overheads of NUCLR

The computational cost of updating $\mathbf{w}$ in NUCLR is $O(B d)$, where $B$ is the batch size and $d$ is the total number of parameters in the model $\mathbf{w}$. This cost is identical to that of SogCLR. The additional computational cost of NUCLR lies in the update of $\zeta$ (line 4 and line 5 of our algorithm).

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{6}$ Each log-sum-exp function is strictly convex along any direction other than diagonal and parallel lines.

The computation of $G\left(\zeta_{t}^{(j)}\right)$ w.r.t. $\zeta_{t}^{(j)}$ in (14) requires $\left\{u_{t+1}^{(i)}\right\}_{i \in \mathcal{B}_{t}}$ and $\frac{\partial}{\partial \zeta^{(i)}} \phi_{i}\left(\mathbf{w}_{t}, \boldsymbol{\zeta}_{t}, \mathcal{B}_{t}\right)$. Here $\left\{u_{t+1}^{(i)}\right\}_{i \in \mathcal{B}_{t}}$ is also needed in SogCLR so it does not result in additional cost. Besides, note that $\frac{\partial}{\partial \zeta^{(i)}} \phi_{i}\left(\mathbf{w}_{t}, \boldsymbol{\zeta}_{t}, \mathcal{B}_{t}\right)=-\frac{n-1}{(B-1) \tau} \exp \left(\frac{E_{\mathbf{w}_{t}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)-E_{\mathbf{w}_{t}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)-\zeta_{t}^{(j)}}{\tau}\right)$, where the shaded part is already computed in the forward propagation and does not incur additional cost. The computation of the gradient w.r.t. $\zeta_{t}^{(j)}$ only involves a summation of $B$ scalars such that the computational cost of line 4 and line 5 of NUCLR is only $O\left(B^{2}\right)$. Since $d$ exceeds 70 million in our experiments, the $O\left(B^{2}\right)$ additional computational cost of NUCLR is negligible compared to the dominant $O(B d)$ term.

Compared to SogCLR, NUCLR needs to store one extra $n$-dimensional vector $\boldsymbol{\zeta}$. Maintaining $\boldsymbol{\zeta}$ in GPU only requires less than 100 MB for 12 million data points, which is negligible compared to the GPU memory required for backpropagation. Moreover, we may instead maintain the vector $\boldsymbol{\zeta}$ in CPU and only transfer those needed $\left\{\zeta^{(j)}\right\}_{j \in \mathcal{B}_{t}}$ to GPU in each iteration. The overhead can be further reduced by overlapping the communication and computation.

# F. 2 MARGIN INTERPRETATION OF NUCLR 

Cross-entropy and contrastive losses with a positive additive margin have been widely studied in the literature (Li et al., 2002; Liu et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2018; Cao et al., 2019; Li et al., 2019; Zhu et al., 2020), which can be viewed as a smooth version of the hinge loss to separate the matching (positive) pair $\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)$ from negative pairs $\left\{\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right) \mid \mathbf{y}_{j} \neq \mathbf{y}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j} \in \mathcal{Y}\right\}$. In supervised learning tasks such as face verification and multi-class classification, using a relatively large positive margin has been shown to be beneficial (Wang et al., 2018; Cao et al., 2019). However, the "false negative" issue is more pronounced in self-supervised learning. Determining the appropriate (positive or negative) margin becomes more difficult, as aggressively and uniformly pushing negative pairs away from positive pairs may hurt the performance (Xie et al., 2022). As shown in the objective in (11), our NUCLR algorithm adopts an individualized negative margin $\zeta^{(j)}$ for each negative data $\mathbf{y}_{j}$ when updating the model parameter $\mathbf{w}$. Rather than relying on an expensive grid search for individualized margins, our method learns them in a principled way. Recall $\zeta^{(j)}$ can serve as a measure of the popularity since $\hat{q}^{(j)} \propto \exp \left(\zeta^{(j)} / \tau\right)$ when $\zeta^{(j)}$ is optimized. As a result, NUCLR may help tolerate potential false negatives because the negative margin $\zeta^{(j)}$ between pairs $\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)$ and $\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}\right)$ is larger when $\mathbf{y}_{j}$ is popular, as it is more likely to be a false negative.

## G More Experimental Results
## G. 1 Detailed Setup of the Toy Experiment in Section 3.3

We construct a dataset $\hat{\mathbf{S}}=\left\{\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{i}\right)\right\}_{i=1}^{n}$ by uniformly sampling $\mathbf{x}_{1}, \ldots, \mathbf{x}_{n}$ from $\mathcal{X}$ and then sampling each $\mathbf{y}_{j}$ from $p_{j}=p\left(\cdot \mid \mathbf{x}_{j}\right)$ by rejection sampling. The ground-truth $\mathbf{q}$ can be computed by the analytic expression of $p(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x})$. To solve the optimization problem in (8), we initialize $\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{0}=\mathbf{0}_{n}$ and obtain $\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{*}$ and $\hat{\mathbf{q}}^{\prime}=\exp \left(\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{*} / \tau\right)$ by running gradient descent until the gradient norm $\leq 10^{-10}$. Besides, we estimate the true risk $\mathcal{L}=-\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}}[\tau \log p(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x})]$ by $-\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N} \tau \log p\left(\mathbf{y}_{i} \mid \mathbf{x}_{i}\right)$ on $N=50,000$ sampled pairs and estimate $Z>0$ by $\frac{\left|\hat{\mathbf{q}}^{\prime}\right|_{\infty}}{\left\|\mathbf{q}\right\|_{\infty}}$ to obtain $\hat{\mathbf{q}}=\frac{\hat{\mathbf{q}}^{\prime}}{Z}$. Then we plug $\hat{\mathbf{q}}$ into (5) to calculate our empirical risk $\hat{\mathcal{L}}$. It is worth noting that estimating the true risk $\mathcal{L}$ and the constant $Z$ is only for the plots in Figure 2, which is not necessary for real-world empirical risk minimization problems.

## G. 2 Additional Plot of the Toy Experiment in Section 3.3

To further verify whether the non-diminishing error might be worse under long-tailed data distributions, we added a new experiment in Figure 7, Appendix G. 1 of our revised manuscript. We still use the data spaces $\mathcal{X}, \mathcal{Y}$, and the density function $p(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x})$ as defined in the last paragraph in Pg. 6 of our paper. Here we consider two values $\tau=0.2$ and $\tau=1.0$, where $\tau=0.2$ results in a more long-tailed distribution of $\mathbf{q}$ compared to $\tau=1.0$. As demonstrated in Figure 6, the generalization error and the error term $\mathcal{E}(\hat{\mathbf{q}}, \mathbf{q} ; \hat{\mathbf{S}})$ of GCL are worse (larger) when $\mathbf{q}$ is long-tailed. Moreover, our method effectively reduces the error term $\mathcal{E}(\hat{\mathbf{q}}, \mathbf{q} ; \hat{\mathbf{S}})$ and the generalization error in both cases.

# G. 3 More Bimodal Experimental Results
## G.3.1 COMPARISON WITH iSogCLR

In Section 4 of the main paper, both our algorithm NUCLR and baselines (CLIP, CyCLIP, DCL, SogCLR) use a shared temperature parameter $\tau$ for all data pairs. In contrast, the iSogCLR algorithm (Qiu et al., 2023) learns an individual temperature parameter for each pair of data. Here we compare the testing performance of our NUCLR algorithm to that of iSogCLR. The results show that our NUCLR outperforms iSogCLR on most metrics except for the zero-shot classification on ImageNet1k when pre-trained on the CC12M dataset. Lastly, we note that the individual temperature learned by the approach in iSogCLR could also be incorporated into our algorithm.

## G.3.2 EFFECT OF THE INITIAL VALUE $\zeta_{0}$

We also investigate the performance of NUCLR with two different initial values $\zeta_{0}$ of the auxiliary variable $\zeta$ : 1) The natural choice $\zeta_{0}=0$; and 2) The value $\zeta_{0}=-0.05$ according to EqCo (Zhu et al., 2020). As seen in Table 3, $\zeta_{0}=-0.05$ performs better on the CC3M dataset while $\zeta_{0}=0$ yields better results on the CC12M dataset. It is worth noting that our NUCLR algorithm, with either initialization $\zeta_{0}$, leads to overall better performance than SogCLR.

# G.3.4 Evaluations on More Datasets 

We empirically compare our NUCLR and baselines on two more datasets for downstream zeroshot classification other than the three used in Section 4: DTD (Cimpoi et al., 2014) is a texture recognition dataset that contains textural images in the wild from 47 classes; Food-101 (Bossard et al., 2014) is a food recognition dataset containing 25,250 food images from 101 categories.

Table 4: A comparison of test performance on two more datasets. The best results are highlighted in black.

![table_3](table_3)

Our algorithm demonstrates superior overall test performance on these two datasets.

abstract:
We study the discriminative probabilistic modeling on a continuous domain for
the data prediction task of (multimodal) self-supervised representation
learning. To address the challenge of computing the integral in the partition
function for each anchor data, we leverage the multiple importance sampling
(MIS) technique for robust Monte Carlo integration, which can recover
InfoNCE-based contrastive loss as a special case. Within this probabilistic
modeling framework, we conduct generalization error analysis to reveal the
limitation of current InfoNCE-based contrastive loss for self-supervised
representation learning and derive insights for developing better approaches by
reducing the error of Monte Carlo integration. To this end, we propose a novel
non-parametric method for approximating the sum of conditional probability
densities required by MIS through convex optimization, yielding a new
contrastive objective for self-supervised representation learning. Moreover, we
design an efficient algorithm for solving the proposed objective. We
empirically compare our algorithm to representative baselines on the
contrastive image-language pretraining task. Experimental results on the CC3M
and CC12M datasets demonstrate the superior overall performance of our
algorithm. Our code is available at https://github.com/bokun-wang/NUCLR.
